awd_titl_txt: Toward Curricular Guidelines for Cybersecurity Education: Defining Educational Standards for an Emerging Discipline
awd_abstract_narration:
Given the imbalance between the demand for cybersecurity professionals and the supply provided by the nation's higher education enterprise, there is an expectation of rapid growth in the number of cybersecurity-related academic programs in the near future. The proposed project will take important steps towards defining comprehensive curricular standards for cybersecurity education and its outcomes can potentially transform cybersecurity education in the US and internationally. The project includes the full participation of academia, government and industry stakeholders throughout the development process and in key leadership roles. It also recognizes that the development of a strong cybersecurity workforce is a global concern and the project invites global contributions to curriculum development efforts.

The Cyber Education Project (CEP) was started in 2014 with the dual goals of(1)establishing curricular guidelines for undergraduate cybersecurity programs that are endorsed by the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) and the IEEE Computer Society; and 2)developing discipline-specific criteria that would lead to the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology (ABET) Cyber Sciences accreditation. The work to be performed through this proposal addresses mostly the first goal - it will establish curricular guidelines for cybersecurity undergraduate programs that are endorsed by major global computing associations - but it will also inform the ABET accreditation process. The activities and deliverables will include organization of the International Security Education Workshop in June 2016 and disseminating the associated workshop report; a curricular volume providing guidelines for cybersecurity undergraduate programs; and roadmaps to guide the implementation of the curricular guidance for a range of constituency groups. The project plans for broad community engagement across the range of academic constituencies - to include computing disciplines, social and behavioral science disciplines, and applied content areas. It will also provide a continuous formative assessment and adjustment throughout the curriculum development process.

por.por_cntn:
"Toward Curricular Guidelines for Cybersecurity Education: Defining Educational Standards for an Emerging Discipline" supported the development and dissemination of the first set of comprehensive cybersecurity curricular guidelines for colleges and universities around the world.

Intellectual Merit - Through the project, members of a joint task force established by the four largest global computing societies - the Association for Computing Machinery, The IEEE Computer Society, the International Federation for Information Processing (IFIP), and the Association for Information Systems (AIS), were able to establish the boundaries of the discipline of cybersecurity, define the core knowledge requirements within a full body of knowledge, and identify strategies for linking cybersecurity with other academic disciplines. The resulting volume, CSEC2017, provides comprehensive guidance for program development and a foundation for future evolution of the field.

Broader Impacts - The comprehensive development process was designed to engage stakeholders across all types of educational institutions, and from global academic, government, and industry sectors. The task force included multiple global surveys, workshops, and community meetings to gather a range of perspectives and information on the curricular requirements. The guidelines were developed and published in 2018. Several exemplars were developed to highlight how a variety of colleges and universities implemented the guidelines. In addition, the task force members created roadmaps to link the curricular guidelines to the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) workforce framework.

Since their release, the guidelines have been disseminated broadly through publications, conference workshops and special sessions hosted by the professional societies, special seminars held at academic institutions to engage faculty members and assist with the implementation of the guidelines, publications, and websites. They continue to have global impact and have been used as critical input for subsequent cybersecurity curricular efforts within the discipline for K-12 education and in adjacent disciplines like data science.
